articles.title: Hurricane Melissa a ‘real-time case study’ of colonialism’s legacies
articles.trailText: Destruction in Jamaica shows why climate justice cannot be separated from reparatory justice, campaigners say
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, a category 5 storm, devastated rural Hanover, Jamaica, inflicting major to severe damage to 15% of 146,000 assessed buildings, killing 45, leaving 13 missing and affecting 360,000 people. Iconic Gurney’s Mount Baptist church lost its roof yet preserved its 1838 freedom stone. At COP30, Jamaican economist Mariama Williams and the Global Afrodescendant Climate Justice Collaborative highlighted how colonialism and enslavement created these vulnerabilities, urging reparatory justice, debt relief and sustained climate funding beyond insurance payouts. Caribbean academics and CARICOM’s Reparations Commission argued climate justice is inseparable from historical reparations.

articles.title: ‘We were forced to burn bodies’: will survivors of the Tadamon massacres see justice?
articles.trailText: The long read: During the conflict, the Damascus suburb became a killing field. But some of Assad’s henchmen are still around – and even working with the new government
articles.summary: In Damascus’s Tadamon district, survivors recount daily torture pits and burning of bodies by Assad’s military intelligence and allied paramilitaries between 2012 and 2015. Leaked footage identified 288 civilians executed in a single massacre and exposed the shooter, Amjad Youssef, who remains unpunished. Despite Assad’s fall in December 2024, many perpetrators—like NDF commander Fadi Saqr—operate openly under Syria’s new government, fueling public outrage and sporadic revenge killings. Residents describe mass graves unearthed by stray dogs, forced child labor to incinerate remains, and ongoing fear. With only a handful of arrests, Tadamon’s quest for accountability and transitional justice remains fraught and incomplete.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: Britain’s dedicated band of rainfall measurers
articles.trailText: From Anglesey to Ben Nevis and Burnley, observers have been gathering invaluable data for hundreds of years
articles.summary: Since Richard Towneley’s first systematic rain gauge in 1677 at Burnley, Britain’s rainfall observers have amassed centuries-long records. By 1860, George Symons founded the British Rainfall Organisation to collate hundreds of gauges nationwide. Mountaineer Clement Wragge walked a 14-mile round trip daily to Ben Nevis in 1881 for data, while Tom Bown, observing since age ten in 1948 on Anglesey, holds 75 years of records and an MBE. These rich archives underpin weather forecasting and climate models, but scientists warn volunteer contributions have declined, resulting in more data collected in the 1880s than in the past decade.

articles.title: When I met Craig he was 13 and homeless. I still thought his life might turn around. I was tragically wrong
articles.trailText: The long read: I knew he was running away from something. It wasn’t until many years later that I discovered the truth
articles.summary: In 1998, 13-year-old Craig ran away from a Nottingham children’s home, living rough in alleys, derelict squats and short-term hostels. Documentary filmmaker Pam traced his life: unaddressed sexual and physical abuse at Beechwood House, fractured family ties and systemic neglect. As an adult, Craig cycled through prison sentences, heroin addiction and low-level crime, briefly finding stability via church housing and art therapy with prison chaplains. Despite intermittent support, institutionalisation and mental health struggles persisted. Found dead at 41 in June 2025, his story exposes failures in child care, social services, housing and the justice system.

articles.title: The Crunch: the decline of Australian children’s TV; rivers in the sky; and where is western Europe?
articles.trailText: Streaming services may be forced to produce Australian content if the Labor’s long-awaited legislation passes parliament this week
articles.summary: Australia’s streaming giants (Netflix, Stan, Disney+) could be mandated to produce local drama, children’s and documentary content if Labor’s bill passes, aiming to reverse the slump to just 35 hrs of kids’ TV in 2023/24 after the Coalition scrapped quotas in 2020. Five charts spotlight: Gaza’s monumental recovery beneath 61 m t of rubble; hurricane-hunter aircraft probing storms like Melissa; rising integrated vapour transport fuelling floods (e.g., Spain 2024); conflicting definitions of western Europe; and the US census’s race categories evolving from a single ‘white’ option in 1790 to multiple identities after 2000.

articles.title: Flags and Christian nationalist slogans feature in soaring attacks on UK mosques
articles.trailText: Between July and October, 25 buildings were targeted in 27 attacks, according to British Muslim Trust
articles.summary: British Muslim Trust data shows 27 attacks on 25 UK mosques between July and October, over a quarter violent. More than 40% featured British or English flags and Christian nationalist slogans (“Christ is king”, “Jesus is king”). Incidents rose from one in July to eight in August, nine in September and October, including arson in East Sussex, air-gun shots in Merseyside, vandalism in Manchester and Glasgow, graffiti and repeat targeting. Appointed in July to monitor Islamophobia, BMT links the surge to hard-right campaigns like Raise the Colours, cites limited police follow-up, and calls for rapid response protocols, streamlined security funding and mosque cohesion education.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: reduced European snowfall spells disaster for skiing
articles.trailText: Swiss researchers have quantified snow loss for the first time, and the figures have far-reaching economic impacts
articles.summary: Swiss study quantifies 8 cm snowfall lost per decade over 25 years across 350 stations, nearly wiping snow cover in the lower Swiss plain while higher peaks remain stable. Ski resorts at 1,500–3,600 m face huge variability; low-altitude venues incur soaring energy bills (snow machines up to 50% of costs) to maintain slopes. The Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research shares data with operators, ski businesses and tourists via apps, warning of looming economic threats to lower resorts as climate change curbs natural snowfall.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: will St Martin’s Day geese predict a white Christmas?
articles.trailText: According to folklore, the weather on St Martin’s Day is a glimpse of the winter ahead and geese are said to sense it first
articles.summary: According to medieval and contemporary folklore, St Martin’s Day on November 11 offers a weather glimpse via goose behavior: mud on Martinmas signals snowy or icy Christmas, while ice under geese foretells a muddy festive season. The tradition stems from 4th-century French Saint Martin, betrayed by honking geese when he hid in their pen. Martinmas feasts slay these geese—allegedly the saint’s revenge—and preserve their wishbones for winter divination. Johannes Hartlieb (1455) noted wagers and Teutonic knights relied on goose-bone forecasts. Modern meteorologists, however, remain cautious without saintly sanction.

articles.title: The tragedy of El Fasher: inside the 7 November Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: A Sudanese massacre foretold. Plus Margaret Atwood on our dystopian world
articles.summary: Guardian Weekly’s 7 November issue reveals genocidal-scale massacres around El Fasher airport in Darfur—satellite imagery shows burning vehicles, blood pools and mass graves as RSF paramilitaries, armed by the UAE, overran the last UN-protected city, triggering UN warnings of “even darker hell” for hundreds of thousands. Rachel Savage and Carlos Mureithi provide on-the-ground analysis, while Nesrine Malik urges the world not to avert its gaze. Also in this edition: Margaret Atwood on our dystopian reality, COP30 leadership stakes, and cultural deep dives from film to football.

articles.title: ‘At the mercy of nature’: how the Caribbean is dealing with the unprecedented Hurricane Melissa
articles.trailText: The category 5 storm has wreaked havoc in the region, as those affected now reckon with damaged livelihoods and the cost of rebuilding
articles.summary: One week after Hurricane Melissa made landfall as a record-breaking Category 5 storm, Jamaica and neighbouring islands remain cut off by landslides and floods that obliterated homes, shops and infrastructure. Low-lying communities face trauma, lost livelihoods and mental-health strains while climate-driven ocean warming is blamed for the hurricane's intensity. Caribbean leaders demand reparations from high-emitting nations to fund reconstruction, a move backed by the diaspora's concert drives and celebrity campaigns. Urgent efforts to future-proof islands intensify ahead of next hurricane season.

articles.title: MPs urge minister to adopt definition of Islamophobia amid rise in hate crime
articles.trailText: Forty Labour and independent MPs call on Steve Reed to take ‘important step’ of defining anti-Muslim hatred
articles.summary: Forty Labour and independent MPs, led by Afzal Khan, have urged Housing Secretary Steve Reed to adopt a formal definition of Islamophobia, citing a 19% rise in anti-Muslim hate crimes in 2025—with Muslims targeted in 45% of religious offences, a 92% increase since 2023. A government working group chaired by Dominic Grieve KC has drafted a non-statutory definition for consultation. MPs want adoption during Islamophobia Awareness Month to curb prejudice while safeguarding free speech and legitimate criticism of Islam.

articles.title: ‘A sense of freedom’: 80 years on from the Pan-African Congress in Manchester
articles.trailText: The legacy of this pivotal event in Black history continues to echo across countries and generations with its call for unity
articles.summary: In Manchester, October 2025 marked the 80th anniversary of the 5th Pan-African Congress held at Chorlton-on-Medlock Town Hall in 1945. This pivotal gathering, chaired by W.E.B. Du Bois and attended by future leaders Nkrumah, Kenyatta, Padmore and others, catalysed anti-colonial struggles across Africa and the Caribbean. Under the banner of Black unity and liberation, local activists like Len Johnson and Alma La Badie shaped UK anti-racist organising. Contemporary celebrations—from the See My World festival and theatrical productions to seminars and exhibitions—underscore its enduring legacy amid rising anti-Black sentiment, reparations campaigns and renewed pan-African cooperation.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: autumn colours linger as growing seasons get longer
articles.trailText: Less frequent but more extreme bursts of rain have shifted autumn back by around two weeks over the past 40 years
articles.summary: Research using satellite imagery and weather data from 1982 to 2020 indicates that growing seasons in mid-to-high latitude Northern Hemisphere have lengthened and autumn leaf colour has been delayed by about two weeks. Fewer but more extreme rainfall events, alongside increased total seasonal precipitation, keep soils moist longer and boost mineralization, supplying plants with more moisture and nitrogen to extend leaf retention. Published in Geophysical Research Letters, the findings refine predictions of climate-change impacts on plant phenology and carbon sequestration.

articles.title: Putin under pressure? Inside the 31 October Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Will US sanctions squeeze Russia’s war machine? Plus: The art genius of Gerhard Richter
articles.summary: This Guardian Weekly edition examines President Trump’s new sanctions on Russian oil and their potential to undermine Putin’s war finances, featuring analyses from Pjotr Sauer and Christopher S Chivvis plus frontline reporting from Kupiansk by Peter Beaumont. Additional features include Heather Stewart on the economics of populism, Patrick Greenfield on deadly elephant migrations, David Shariatmadari’s interview with Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales, Simon Tisdall on truth and justice in Gaza, and Adrian Searle on Gerhard Richter’s art.

articles.title: A sprawling global family: The Long Wave turns one
articles.trailText: As we celebrate our first anniversary, we reflect on the stories that connect us across the diaspora
articles.summary: The Long Wave celebrates its first anniversary by revisiting standout dispatches that unite the global Black diaspora: Sudanese-British artist Elmiene fuses heritage and music against a backdrop of war and displacement; Brazil’s largest African-descended community fights for cultural ownership; Michelle Obama shifts from political icon to candid podcast host; Barbados’s Crop Over festival delivers a liberating diaspora ritual; Keshia Sakarah’s Caribe cookbook archives Caribbean ingredients as identity anchors; and Nigeria’s Super Falcons secure a tenth Women’s Africa Cup with a trademark ‘chaos-driven’ mental edge. Data reveals “No Kings Day” anti-Trump protests on Xylom with a median 5 million participants—likely the largest single-day political protest ever—and charts cumulative protests in Trump’s potential second term. articles.title: Weatherwatch: Myths behind the capricious god of the north wind
articles.trailText: Boreas, whose icy winds herald winter, was regarded as saboteur of heroes and saviour of cities by ancient Greeks
articles.summary: Boreas, the winged god of the north wind in Greek myth, was famed for his icy blasts that heralded winter and could wreck heroes like Odysseus and Hercules. Yet ancient city-states also invoked him as a saviour: in 480 BC an oracle-led prayer summoned a three-day northerly storm that annihilated the Persian fleet off Athens, earning Boreas a temple and the annual Boreasmus festival. He later protected Megalopolis from Spartan attack and destroyed a Syracusan armada menacing Thuria, which built him a temple and granted him citizen rights. His capricious gusts embodied both peril and protection.

articles.title: A victory for gen Z: inside the 24 October Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: A revolution in Madagascar. Plus: Virginia Giuffre in her own words
articles.summary: In the 24 October Guardian Weekly, Gen Z-led student protests in Madagascar forced President Andry Rajoelina from power, part of a global wave of leaderless youth movements against corrupt elites and economic stagnation. A memoir extract from Virginia Giuffre details her exploitation and alleged sexual encounters with Prince Andrew, a narrative the royal family seeks to bury. The issue also examines cross-border far-right fight clubs, political rows delaying Nigeria’s West African art museum, graphene’s stalled commercialisation, controversial English tests for immigrants and a fresh Black-led production of Othello.

articles.title: Black History Month is a reflection of the political moment, so how do we revamp it?
articles.trailText: The aim is to address systemic and institutional racism but those efforts need the space to expand not shrink
articles.summary: UK’s Black History Month, conceived in 1926 as a week-long commemoration by Carter G. Woodson and later adopted in October, has shifted from historical and cultural celebration to a corporate-led “bias” industry marked by tokenism. Amid a domestic and global right-wing resurgence, legal assaults on DEI and efforts to erase Black experiences, critics call to extend it year-round, embed content in schools, foreground youth voices and current injustices, and demand structural change—possibly rebranding it as “Black History Is Now Month.”

articles.trailText: Relief and uncertainty in Gaza and Israel. Plus: Malala Yousafzai on growing up and choosing happiness
articles.summary: After two years of war, Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire under the US president’s 20-point Gaza plan, prompting relief alongside unresolved questions over Gaza’s future governance, reconstruction, an international stabilisation force, Israeli troop redeployment and Hamas disarmament. Seham Tantesh reports from Gaza on cautious optimism and searches for closure; Daniel Boffey captures the atmosphere in Tel Aviv’s Hostages Square after remaining captives’ release; Patrick Wintour traces the diplomatic manoeuvres behind the deal. articles.title: Proposed UK Islamophobia definition allows for right to criticise religion, source says
articles.trailText: Source says working group stuck to requirement that definition must not interfere with freedom of speech
articles.summary: UK working group on Islamophobia, chaired by Dominic Grieve, submitted a private non-statutory definition to Communities Secretary Steve Reed, stipulating respect for freedom of speech—including the right to criticise, insult or oppose Islam—to avoid curbing legitimate debate. Critics fear restrictions on religious critique, recalling the 2019 APPG definition branded racist and too broad. Comprising Muslim community figures (e.g. Shaista Gohir, Akeela Ahmed) and academics, the panel’s draft avoids a backdoor blasphemy law and will enter consultation if adopted. Government data show anti-Muslim hate crimes rose 19% to 3,199 offences (Apr ’24–Mar ’25), while officials stress no decisions made and reaffirm protection of religious criticism.

articles.title: Muslim women do not need saving, says female leader of mosque at centre of charity run row
articles.trailText: East London Mosque received hateful emails after event for men, boys, and under-12 girls only – but organisers say women’s race was undersubscribed
articles.summary: Sufia Alam, head of programmes at East London Mosque in Tower Hamlets, defended staging a male, boys and under-12 girls only Muslim Charity Run after a women’s race was undersubscribed. She said Muslim women “don’t need saving,” criticised outsider assumptions and highlighted existing women-only sports and community spaces. Chief executive Junaid Ahmed cited intensified Islamophobic hate mail and increased security, while crossbench peer Shaista Gohir warned against stereotyping. The Equality and Human Rights Commission is reviewing the event and the mosque will open a women’s health and wellbeing hub next year.

articles.title: Starmer orders NHS antisemitism review after ‘clear cases not dealt with adequately’
articles.trailText: Prime minister also announces £10m funding to provide security for Jewish amenities, including synagogues and schools
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer has ordered an urgent NHS antisemitism review, led by government adviser John Mann, after “clear cases” by doctors went unpunished. The Department of Health confirmed impunity for racist staff prompted the probe, which will assess patient and staff protection and accountability. Starmer also pledged £10m for security at synagogues and Jewish schools and urged NHS England to adopt the IHRA definition. He criticised universities, notably Oxford, for slow responses to campus incidents. The measures follow rising hate crime, a recent synagogue attack and a July review flagging NHS-specific antisemitism. The government will also examine Islamophobic hate crime support.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: autumn gales divert migrating birds, to UK birders’ delight
articles.trailText: Sabine’s gulls and phalaropes among species that found themselves venturing unexpectedly close to land
articles.summary: After a warm, dry summer in Somerset followed by a ‘final hurrah’ of lingering heat, despite autumn’s occasional bite, late August through mid-September westerly gales and the tail-end of Hurricane Erin unexpectedly pushed normally offshore pelagic seabirds toward the South West UK shoreline. Somerset coast watchers recorded a juvenile Sabine’s gull on its first southbound flight from Greenland, joining flocks totalling as many as 1,700 off Ireland, Wales and SW England. Inland at a local reservoir, rare grey and scarcer red-necked phalaropes paused to refuel, enthralling birders for a week before continuing migration under clearer, calmer autumn skies.

articles.title: ‘The jobless should lead the attack’: a radical Jamaican journalist in 1920s London
articles.trailText: The long read: Economic insecurity, race riots, incendiary media … Claude McKay was one of the few Black journalists covering a turbulent period that sounds all too familiar to us today
articles.summary: Jamaican-born poet and journalist Claude McKay, shaken by the US Red Summer of 1919 and his sonnet “If We Must Die,” relocated to London amid postwar race riots. Facing discrimination in housing, pubs and on the docks, McKay became labour correspondent and essayist for Sylvia Pankhurst’s Workers’ Dreadnought, exposing imperial exploitation, dock strikes and racial violence. Under pseudonyms, he challenged mainstream press racism, faced surveillance and censorship, and helped radicalise Britain’s left. After police raids in 1920, he returned to New York in 1921, later shaping the Harlem Renaissance and global anti-colonial debates.

articles.title: The two sides of Kemi Badenoch: how the Tory leader pivoted for political gain
articles.trailText: As her fortunes shift and change, the MP for North West Essex, who is of Nigerian heritage has embraced pragmatism and contradiction to survive
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch has morphed from Kemi Adegoke, who championed Nigerian unity—forming Nigerians for Kemi in 2010—to a hard-right Tory leader who distances herself from her heritage. Ahead of her first anniversary in charge, she backed Trump-style mass deportations, defended MP Robert Jenrick’s call for more “white faces,” and dismissed systemic racism as overstated. Facing poor poll numbers and internal sceptics questioning her Britishness, she now warns of creeping “ethno-nationalism” and leaves open a future re-embrace of her Nigerian identity.

articles.title: ‘Hot mic’ hot mess: gaffes made by global leaders when they think no one is listening
articles.trailText: Indonesia’s Prabowo is the latest world leader to fall foul of the ‘hot mic’ – diplomatic snafus that have caused embarrassment to leaders around the globe
articles.summary: At a Gaza peace summit, Indonesian president Prabowo Subianto was overheard on a hot mic asking Donald Trump to set up calls with his Trump Organization-executive sons. This high-profile slip joins others: Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin discussing organ transplants and immortality; Australia's Peter Dutton quipping about Pacific Islanders and sea-level rise; Gordon Brown branding a voter "bigoted"; Barack Obama and Nicolas Sarkozy calling Netanyahu a liar; and George W. Bush dubbing a New York Times reporter a "major league asshole."

articles.trailText: Need something brilliant to read this weekend? Here are six of our favourite pieces from the last seven days
articles.summary: An omnibus of six standout pieces: Jens Stoltenberg’s gripping account of how Donald Trump nearly derailed NATO; interviews with the 1980s ‘Filthy Fifteen’ rock icons caught in a moral panic over ‘objectionable’ music; The White Lotus star Lukas Gage on trauma, mental health and his candid memoir; Philip Oltermann’s investigation of a cross-border heist of rare Pushkin volumes; Lionel Richie’s reflections on America’s political climate, civil rights roots and friendship with Michael Jackson; and Zoe Williams’s deep dive into the boom—and potential downsides—of radical individualist self-help books.

articles.title: With most MPs ignorant of the urgency, how can the UK ever reach net zero?
articles.trailText: Only 15 of 100 MPs surveyed knew of IPCC report that CO 2 needs to peak this year to keep global heating to 1.5C
articles.summary: A survey of 100 UK MPs, conducted pre-election, found only 15 knew the IPCC’s 2022 finding that CO2 emissions must peak by 2025 to limit warming to 1.5°C; 30% believed the deadline was 2040 or later. Labour MPs outperformed Conservatives in identifying the correct year. With most MPs unaware of the urgency, informed cross-party debate on policies to achieve net zero by 2050 is hampered, raising doubts over the UK’s ability to meet its Paris-aligned climate commitments.

articles.title: The Crunch: far-right Facebook groups; underpaid WNBA players; and making your own origami bird
articles.trailText: Our colleagues in the UK spent a year studying an online community trading in anti-immigration sentiment and misinformation
articles.summary: The Guardian’s The Crunch investigates far-right Facebook networks trading anti-immigrant conspiracies, mapped via a year of AI-driven analysis. It also visualises food shrinkflation, the vast WNBA–NBA pay gap, record ocean heat risks in Australia, and interfaith marriage trends from census data. Finally, it highlights Guardian Australia’s biannual bird-of-the-year vote and includes a DIY illustrated origami bird tutorial.

articles.title: Strike faking: how lightning can be simulated to check equipment is safe
articles.trailText: Test pulses from lightning impulse generators can be used to ensure lightning protection is functioning properly
articles.summary: UK regulations require lightning protection on schools, high-rise flats, churches and factories, enforced through annual inspections that visually confirm intact lightning rods, proper grounding and functional surge protectors. For electrical equipment, technicians may use portable lightning impulse generators—roughly the size of a small fridge—using a bank of rapidly discharged capacitors known as a Marx generator—to simulate a short, million-volt pulse. Although these test pulses carry far less energy than real lightning, they replicate its voltage profile to verify protective circuits, connectors and surge arrestors, ensuring devices and structures remain operational in an actual strike.

articles.title: Manchester’s day of darkness: inside the 10 October Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: A community reeling from terror attack. Plus: Trump’s chilling message to liberal donors
articles.summary: Guardian Weekly’s 10 October issue examines the Yom Kippur terror attack in north Manchester, where Jihad al-Shamie rammed a car into synagogue gates then stabbed worshippers, killing two civilians before armed police shot him. Survivors reflect on rising antisemitism and calls for solidarity. Further coverage includes David Smith on Trump’s chilling message to Democratic donors; Jillian Pretzel on maintenance insomnia; Samanth Subramanian on Tonga’s cut cables; Simon Tisdall on US forces near Venezuela; Alexis Petridis on a new Springsteen biopic; plus interviews with Evan Dando and a 2025 beauty advent calendar guide.

articles.title: ‘This is a west African story’: how modern art tackled Nigeria’s identity crisis
articles.trailText: As the landmark Nigerian Modernism exhibition opens at the Tate, curator Osei Bonsu talks about the art in dialogue with ideas of nation-making
articles.summary: Nigerian Modernism at Tate Modern (to May 10) foregrounds how artists from indirect colonial rule to post-1960 independence negotiated Nigeria’s identity. Curated by Osei Bonsu and Bilal Akkouche, it reclaims modern art from “traditional” framing through works like Aina Onabolu’s 1922 portrait of Charlotte Obasa, Akinola Lasekan’s everyday and mythological scenes, and Jonathan Adagogo Green’s post-1897 photographs of Oba Ovonramwen. Highlights include Olowe of Ise’s carved door panel reversing colonial power, Ben Enwonwu’s Negritude and Storm Over Biafra, Zaria Art Society’s decolonizing pedagogy, plus Ladi Kwali pottery, El-Anatsui reliefs and adire textiles. Acquisition challenges, restorations with MOWAA, and touring plans underscore the show’s multinational, diasporic narrative.

articles.title: Boom time for US billionaires: why the system perpetuates wealth inequality
articles.trailText: As the super rich grow even richer, inequality expert Chuck Collins says the system is broken – but it can be fixed
articles.summary: In Boom time for US billionaires, Chuck Collins reveals billionaire wealth grew 54% in 2020 while 10% of Americans own 93% of stock assets. He adapts Robert Frank’s “Richistan” to classify tiers from Affluent Town through Lower, Middle and Upper Richistan to 800-person Billionaireville. Collins argues the system uses wealth defense (tax lawyers, offshore trusts), political capture post-Citizens United and hyper-extraction via private equity (e.g., Mars family’s pet care rents) to funnel money upward. He also flags Trump’s billionaire cabinet and stalled Build Back Better reforms, insisting extreme inequality is fixable.

articles.summary: In the aftermath of Thursday’s stabbing and police shooting at Manchester’s Heaton Park synagogue that killed two worshippers and the attacker, CST head of policy Dave Rich warned that antisemitism has been allowed to grow among politicians, in society, mosques and online. He denounced planned pro-Palestine silent vigils by Defend Our Juries in Trafalgar Square and Manchester as self-absorbed and a diversion of police resources needed to protect Jewish communities. articles.title: UK’s Jewish community feels much less safe since 7 October attack, survey finds
articles.trailText: Report says 35% of Jews felt unsafe in Britain and 32% reported at least one antisemitic incident in 2024
articles.summary: JPR’s June–July 2025 survey of British Jews—the largest since the 7 October 2023 Hamas attacks—reports a sharp drop in security perceptions: 35% of respondents felt unsafe (vs 9% in 2023), and 47% view antisemitism as a “very big” problem (11% in 2012). In 2024, 32% experienced at least one antisemitic incident. CST logged 1,521 incidents in H1 2025 (second-highest ever), notably 968 in London/Manchester. Emotional attachment to Israel rose to 75% (49% very attached), while anti-Zionist identification climbed to 12% overall (24% among 20-29s), and 51% now criticize Israel’s Gaza conduct (up from 40%).

articles.title: Georgia supreme court sides with Gullah Geechee residents fighting to protect land
articles.trailText: Decision reversed lower court ruling that weakened zoning restrictions put in place decades ago to preserve lands
articles.summary: On September 30, 2025, the Georgia Supreme Court overturned a lower court ruling that blocked a voter referendum in McIntosh County on zoning changes in Hogg Hummock (Sapelo Island), a Gullah Geechee enclave. Commissioners doubled the maximum home size from 1,400 to 3,000 sq ft in 2023, prompting 2,300+ residents to petition for a special election to repeal the ordinance. Justice John Ellington ruled the referendum process applies to zoning provisions, allowing county voters to decide future development limits and safeguarding the community’s land and culture.

articles.title: On Europe’s frontline: inside the 3 October Guardian Weekly

Chief reporter Daniel Boffey reports from Narva, where a mayoral vote will test the 98% Russian-speaking town’s resilience behind its fortified Bridge of Friendship. Historian Sergey Radchenko draws cold war tactical lessons, while Brussels correspondent Jennifer Rankin explores Moldova’s pro-EU election win. articles.title: ‘It’s a collective validation’: the group helping Black families cope after baby loss
articles.trailText: The founders of Ebony Bonds on poor maternal health outcomes for Black women and how their space confronts the honest reality of dealing with bereavement after the loss of a baby
articles.summary: Ebony Bonds founders Rachel Burrell and Gina Reeves launched in 2023 to help Black UK families bereaved by stillbirth after experiencing neglect by health services. Their “walk and talk” drew 70+ participants, revealing shared trauma: Black babies are stillborn at nearly twice the white rate, and Black women face poorer maternal outcomes. By offering culturally competent peer gatherings, check-ins, resource signposting and events—plus a men’s arm (NINE)—they normalize grief, validate experiences, and mobilize community care through simple acts: acknowledging loss, bringing food, and staying present. Baby Loss Awareness Week runs 9-15 October.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: EU survey gives a few hints on voter-friendly climate policies
articles.trailText: Survey finds 70% of people would support a fare-cutting rail fund – but taxes on beef and flying are less popular
articles.summary: An EU-wide survey finds 70% backing for an EU rail fund to halve ticket fares, 55% for household insulation mandates with subsidies and private jet bans, while taxes on beef, flights and fossil-fuel cars attract far less support. Backing is stronger in southern member states (Greece, France, Italy) than in eastern ones (Poland, Czech Republic), and is highest among younger, better-educated voters. The UK was excluded post-Brexit, but results offer voter-friendly guides for chancellors balancing short-term popularity with long-term climate goals. The survey suggests politically palatable fiscal measures could help advance climate targets without alienating constituents.

articles.title: The Crunch: Australia’s horrifying climate future; finding clothes that fit; and charting the perfect coffee
articles.trailText: Maps using data from Australia’s climate risk report show just how bad things could get for heatwaves, drought and coastal flooding
articles.summary: Three animated maps from Australia’s climate risk report forecast severe spikes in heatwaves, droughts and coastal flooding; RMIT’s Heat Vulnerability Index and Monash University’s heatwave deaths data reveal higher risks in older, disabled and low-income communities. Straits Times’ interactive feature exposes erratic women’s clothing sizes across brands. ABC charts benchmark Australia’s 2035 emissions target against past outputs and 1.5°C pathways. Nicola Rennie’s plot shows chess grandmasters peak in their late 30s. Burn-Murdoch reports French pensioners now earn more than working-age adults. Nicholas Jordan’s scatter plot reviews 41 supermarket coffees by flavor and value.

Additional amended articles include 'All suds, no substance', which found detergent sheets no better than water for stains; Canada's free birth control coverage; Shapiro and Buttigieg's responses to revelations in Kamala Harris's memoir; Claudia Cardinale's overlooked Hollywood impact; and Ed Miliband's revisit of North Sea drilling despite Labour's pledge. articles.title: Weatherwatch: Flash droughts come on quickly but effects can wreak havoc
articles.trailText: Better water management and efficient irrigation required to tackle issue, which can increase risk of wildfires
articles.summary: Flash droughts differ from traditional droughts by an abrupt onset rather than a slow progression. Since the 2010s meteorologists have identified these events—periods under three weeks during which soil moisture in the top 40 cm plunges rapidly—based on Prof. Jason Otkin’s 2018 formal definition, later refined statistically. Triggered by high temperatures, strong winds and low humidity, they cause vegetation stress, crop failures, heightened wildfire risk and sudden water shortages. Often precursors to prolonged dry spells, flash droughts also abruptly reduce water available for human consumption and agriculture. Addressing them requires enhanced forecasting, early warning systems, efficient irrigation and improved water management.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Robert F Kennedy Jr | Mikaela Straus
articles.summary: The Guardian corrects a misquote in its RFK Jr article (he spoke of autism’s “multi-factorial aetiology,” not an “ideology”) and fixes singer-songwriter Mikaela Straus’s name. It also amends earlier stories on a 41-variety coffee taste test, the UN Security Council’s failure to block snapback Iran sanctions, windfarm blade recycling research, Ballarat’s gender-based violence trial, the interim US attorney in the White House, and the revival of Irish road bowling. Editorial corrections: guardian.readers@theguardian.com.

articles.title: Beyond all recognition: inside the 26 September Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Israel, the state of Palestine and the UN. Plus: Rightwing America’s free speech paradox
articles.summary: This week Guardian Weekly examines a western coalition’s symbolic recognition of Palestinian statehood at the UNGA—an effort by Britain, France, Canada, Australia and Belgium to chastise Israel’s Gaza offensive, deter West Bank annexation and revive two-state talks. Reporters find cautious optimism in Ramallah, a muted Israeli response and unpack practical implications, while Nesrine Malik urges urgent western action on Gaza. Also: Rightwing America’s new ‘consequence culture’ on free speech, dodo de-extinction via gene editing, AI pioneer Song-Chun Zhu’s move to China, Simon Jenkins on Britain’s Trump visit and Marie Antoinette’s fashion comeback.

articles.title: Australia’s horrifying climate future in four charts – and how we can avoid the worst
articles.trailText: Maps released by the Australian Climate Service show just how bad things will get for heatwaves, drought and coastal flooding
articles.summary: The national climate risk assessment explores 10 priority hazards—including bushfires, floods and extreme heat—using ACS data to map worst-case 3°C warming by 2050. Annual severe+extreme heatwave days could more than double, especially in northern Australia, driving heat-related mortality drastically upward—heatwaves caused up to 1,009 deaths from 2016–19. Southern Victoria, SA and WA will endure longer droughts, stressing crops, while coastal flooding days (e.g. Sydney’s rising from 31 to 344 annually past 1995–2014 records) threaten over 1.5 million residents. Urgent emissions cuts remain the only way to avoid these impacts. The ACS’s interactive mapping tool underpins the report, guiding adaptive planning and policy decisions.

articles.title: From the catwalk to the closet, Black designers are using fashion as an antidote to growing division
articles.trailText: In the same patch of London that saw far-right mobilisation, designer Foday Dumbuya provided an expansion on the cultural influences of immigration
articles.summary: At London Fashion Week, Foday Dumbuya’s Labrum show "Osmosis" at Central Hall Westminster offered a cultural counterpoint to far-right protests, exploring "cultural osmosis" through a fusion of British tailoring and West African textiles. The runway blended classical strings, talking drums and digital riddims, featured cowrie-shell motifs and military-style headgear evoking Congolese Ekonda Botolo and the legacies of colonial wars. Alongside, Jawara Alleyne’s "Tabanca" celebrated Caribbean carnival’s post-party "lovesickness", while Tolu Coker’s filmic "Unfinished Business" honoured Black women’s intergenerational heritage—underscoring fashion as a political agent of diasporic dialogue.

articles.title: Women allegedly abused by Andrew Tate decry ‘misleading’ Spectator article
articles.trailText: Complaint sent to Ipso over interview with ‘misogynist influencer’ and brother in Michael Gove-edited magazine
articles.summary: Four women who have filed a high court claim accusing Andrew Tate of rape, coercive control and assault have lodged a complaint with press regulator Ipso over a Spectator interview with Andrew Tate and his brother Tristan by deputy editor Freddy Gray, edited by Michael Gove. They say the piece is inaccurate and misleading, wrongly suggesting Romanian charges “will melt away” and omitting extradition orders. Gray’s uncritical portrayal of the brothers’ denials, his “Hustlers University” platform, and claims of a $50m payoff or “deep state” plot is contested. The Spectator maintains it upholds accuracy and reader judgment.

It lists other recent amendments—spanning articles on US free speech debates, political violence, WNBA semifinals, immigration protests in Glasgow, state pension rules, London borough planning, athletics gold medals, F1 qualifying and human trafficking trials. articles.title: The human stain remover: what Britain’s greatest extreme cleaner learned from 25 years on the job | Tom Lamont
articles.trailText: From murder scenes to whale blubber, Ben Giles has seen it – and cleaned it – all. In their stickiest hours, people rely on him to restore order
articles.summary: Ben Giles, a 49-year-old Welsh extreme cleaner, has spent 25 years restoring order to Britain’s most gruesome scenes—from murder and hoarder properties to a 20-tonne whale carcass—using his self-taught “Giles Method”: tackle stains from the outside in, five-minute chemical “dwell” and bespoke fogged sanitiser (Byotrol 4-in-1). Founder of Ultima (600 freelancers) and now chief consultant at Atlas, he trains operatives in trauma-scene and biohazard cleanup. A Jehovah’s Witness and memoirist, Giles combines technical precision with disciplined immediacy to remove blood, waste and decay, while preserving mental resilience.

articles.title: ‘I’d rather be bored than in danger’: Muslim women change how they behave in public because of racist attacks in Australia
articles.trailText: Islamophobia Register Australia data shows women and girls are subject to 75% of reported incidents. These are some of their stories
articles.summary: Since 2014 Australia’s Islamophobia Register shows 75% of reported anti-Muslim incidents target women and girls, with a 530% surge since October 2023. University student Sarah Alzoubi now avoids headphones and screens on trains after a 2015 Islamophobic sexual harassment. Teacher Mariam Tohamy and her daughter faced spitting, shelf-throwing and throat-slitting gestures in Sydney while wearing hijabs and pro-Palestine tees. Special envoy Aftab Malik and Dr Nora Amath warn that gendered Islamophobia—rooted in racism and sexism—is rising, though only 18% of victims report to police, meaning these figures likely understate the threat.

articles.title: Six great reads: my Couples Therapy hell, the plot to dethrone Keir Starmer and a ‘creepy’ AI toy
articles.trailText: Need something interesting to read this weekend? Here are six of our favourite pieces from the last seven days
articles.summary: Six standout features: Boris Fishman’s turn on TV’s Couples Therapy that crumbled his marriage and made him an online pariah; Pippa Crerar and Jessica Elgot’s exposé on a clandestine bid to topple PM Keir Starmer amidst Labour turmoil; Arwa Mahdawi’s unnerving trial of ‘Grem’, an AI toy that records and analyzes children's speech; Brenda Fricker’s candid memoir interview detailing decades of abuse and survival; Jason Burke’s deep dive into the Baader-Meinhof gang’s violent yet bungled 1970s spree; and Joelle Fraser’s chilling memoir of her mother’s shared psychosis in a remote California cabin.

articles.title: Social media ban trial data reveals racial bias in age checking software: just how inaccurate is it?
articles.trailText: Young people from Indigenous and Asian backgrounds are more likely to be miscategorised as over the age limit and older people as underaged, analysis finds
articles.summary: Guardian analysis of the ACCS age assurance technology trial for Australia’s under-16 social media ban finds age-estimation software miscategorises young people from Indigenous and south-east Asian backgrounds as overage at rates up to 7% higher than white Australians, and misclassifies older users as minors. Face-scanning checks were slower for these groups, and document-based age verification failed for 50% of Indigenous participants in a small sample. The official report downplays demographic disparities, excluding underperforming vendors and undisclosed lab data. High error rates (25–73%) for teens under 16 mean many 16–19-year-olds will need extra checks, while adults face minimal inconvenience.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: Early ripening berries could be bad news for UK’s visiting birds
articles.trailText: The warmest summer on record has brought a premature autumn – which could leave little food for overwintering birds
articles.summary: After the UK’s warmest recorded summer triggered signs of autumn weeks early, hawthorn berries and blackthorn sloes ripened in hedgerows from early August. While foragers might welcome the bumper crop, key winter visitors such as redwings (arriving mid-October from Iceland and Scandinavia) and East European fieldfares rely on a steady autumn supply of fruits to fuel them through winter. This premature peak could leave migrating thrushes facing food shortages, illustrating how shifting seasonal patterns from climate warming are disrupting UK ecosystems and bird migration timing.
